  • Method Details

    • covertToISO2Locale

      public static Locale covertToISO2Locale(Locale locale)
      Converts the provided locale to an instance with ISO 639-1 two letter code - if possible.

      Internally in Java Locale the language codes are not converted. So creating a locale for English with language code "en" is different from creating a locale with language code "eng", although both codes denote the same language. This would not be a problem if only the ISO 639-3 language codes Locale.getISO3Language() are compared. Unfortunately this is not the case with Locale.equals(Object). So creating a locale with language code "eng" is not "equal" to Locale.ENGLISH, as the latter uses a two letter language code "en". So all locales, that have been created with ISO 639-3 codes, should be converted to their two letter codes (ISO 639-1) variants to make them comparable with system locales.

      Conversion is done by listing all available locales and then comparing the ISO 639-3 codes with the provided parameter. If they match, then the matching system locale is returned. If none match or the provided locale already uses two letter language code, then the provided locale is returned unchanged.

      Parameters:
      locale - the locale to check whether conversion is necessary and possible.
      Returns:
      a converted locale if an ISO 639-1 two letter code exists.
